data.title: Soul singer Percy Sledge no stranger to Gastonia
data.meta_description: Soul singer Percy Sledge called Louisiana home, but he always had a place to stay in Gastonia.
data.text:
Soul singer Percy Sledge called Louisiana home, but he always had a place to stay in Gastonia.

Sledge, best known for his 1966 hit, “When a Man Loves a Woman,” died Tuesday at 74.

Local club owner Charles Gunn said he’s sad to know he’ll never hear Sledge sing in Gaston County again.

Frequent face in town

Gunn first hosted a visit from Sledge in 1971.

“When he had that song out, ‘When a Man Loves a Woman,’ everybody was after him,” said Gunn.

And Gastonia got him 23 times, according to Gunn.

The smiling, gap-toothed singer didn’t hesitate to play events in town over the course of decades, Gunn said.

Gunn said he called Sledge’s agent in November, hoping to book another date.

“His agent said he had cancer real bad and wouldn’t be touring anymore,” Gunn said.

The disease ultimately took Sledge’s life.

Private person, singing success

But Gunn remembers a vivacious, gracious Sledge.

Gunn featured Sledge on the stage of the former Dino’s Restaurant and Club. Sledge always stayed after the show and signed autographs until everyone was satisfied, but he also liked some time alone, Gunn said.

“We always wanted him to go to the Shrimp Boat with us, but he was a private person,” said Gunn.

Before he became famous, Sledge worked in the cotton fields around his hometown of Leighton in northwest Alabama and took a job in a nearby hospital.

He spent weekends playing with a rhythm-and-blues band. A hospital patient heard him singing and recommended him to a record producer.

Key to the city

Former Gastonia Mayor Jennie Stultz remembers listening to Sledge on the radio when she was a teenager.

Stultz said she was thrilled years later when she had the opportunity to meet Sledge and present him with a key to the city.

Stultz remembers Sledge saying that when he first started coming to Gastonia, he feared he wouldn’t have a place to stay or might be arrested because of race relations in the country at the time. He never imagined he’d be given a key to the city.

But Sledge never struggled for a place to stay when he was in town, Gunn said.

“People would take him home instead of having him stay in a hotel. Everybody loved Percy,” said Gunn.

Gunn said his love for Sledge and his music never waned, and getting the news of the musician’s passing was tough.

“I think he got better with age,” Gunn said. “He was well known in Gastonia. People really loved him. We’re really going to miss him.”

The Associated Press contributed to this article.

Song’s staying power

“When a Man Loves a Woman”

- Featured in movies including “The Big Chill,” “The Crying Game” and a 1994 Meg Ryan drama named for the song's title.

- Re-released after being featured in Oliver Stone’s Vietnam War film “Platoon” in 1987 and reached No. 2 in Britain.

- Took Michael Bolton to the top of the charts in the 1990s

- Ranked by Rolling Stone magazine as No. 53 on its list of the greatest songs of all time.

Star’s staying power

Percy Sledge had a handful of other hits between 1966 and 1968, including “Warm and Tender Love,” “It Tears Me Up,” “Out of Left Field” and “Take Time to Know Her.”

He returned to the charts in 1974 with "I'll Be Your Everything."

Sledge was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2005.

He was inducted into the Alabama Music Hall of Fame in 1993 and the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame in 2007.

Source: The Associated Press
